text: <@U13TWBRBL> <@U2Q0HP4HY> <@U0YQK8WSV> <@U1Y2R5C9L> just reviewed yesterday's discussion
I'm glad to see that we are trying to collaborate more - this is goodness
I think, though, that there needs to be a change in how we work to enable this level of collaboration

I went through this with the IBM squads, TBH (and some are still being coached;-) so this is not uncommon problem in learning how to be most effective at collaborating in open source with people not sitting in the same office
point one: submit smaller changesets that move the ball slightly, rather than trying to merge a major refactor all at once in the midst of a moving target project as large and as active as Fabric
by small, I mean less than 200 LOC ideally, _with tests_
this could mean that you are adding refactored capability that is not fully enabled excepting via tests until the new capability is fully ready to be activated (eg via feature flag, etc)
Why do I say small? Because smaller changesets means quicker review - a 1k LOC changeset could take a weekend to review
point two: as was suggested above, share the planning and decompose work in discrete tasks that can be independently worked
you can, for instance, write a new function, add its tests (both happy path and the various negative tests) independent of any USE of that new function excepting by the tests
then, once that is merged, you can start to add the calls to the new function (you can even mete this out gradually, again, adding tests where appropriate
May I add we should be opening up JIRA's that describe the work we are doing so it's clearly communicated
absolutely, that is implied in my comment immediately above

if there needs to be a major refactor, then I would strongly recommend that it be discussed in slack or email and that the the agreed approach be documented in JIRA and assignments (short ones!) be meted out
it is important to have as much transparency as possible
and it is important that the changes be incremental so that the disagreements (inevitable) can be minimized
I'd also recommend that there be consideration of adding more maintainers to help with reviews - maybe change the policy to 2+2 to ensure agreement
finally, we should really get Jenkins CI set up for this project
<@U0KM61BCP> Thx for suggestions.. we will definitely start using JIRA to get broader community involvement and to add more committers.  CI is on my todo list.
